714187f-a.text:
417 East 66th Street, north side between York and First
Avenues, showing P.S. 183.
Board of Education, N.Y.W.
NEG~ 17
3737A

724876f-a.text:
Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research, east of York Avenue at 68th Street, showing the original laboratory (to the left) dedicated May 11, 1906, and the little Isolation Building, and the Main Hospital (erected around 1910).  In the right background part of the Queensboro Bridge can be seen. The Avenue of trees leading up to the old laboratory follows the line of 66th Street, which at this point roughly corresponds to the old Schermerhorn Lane.  The Rockefeller Institute was incorporated in 1901, and bought the old Schermerhorn property shown in this picture.
July 31, 1930
P.L. Sperr.

724881f-a.text:
Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research, east of York Avenue from 66th to 67th Streets. From right to left the buildings are: part of the original laboratory (1906), Laboratory No. 2 (1916) and the new laboratory, nearing completion, its south side in line with 67th Street, which has been permanently closed east of York Avenue. In the foreground are gardens and shelters for women and children.
July 31, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.

724878f-a.text:
York Avenue, east side, north from 66th Street, showing the New York Hospital -- Cornell Medical College, nearing completion, from 68th to 71st Streets. The grounds and part of the newest laboratory of the Rockefeller Institute are shown in the foreground and to the right. The building under construction looks like an addition to the Rockefeller Institute but is not; it is a wing of the New York Hospital on the north side of 68th Street.
Early 1931.
Wurts Brothers

724877f-a.text:
York Avenue, east side, north from East 66th Street, showing prominently the New York Hospital--Cornell Medical College after completion. In the foreground are
the grounds of the Rockefeller Institute.
1933
Wurts Brothers

724879f.text:
York Avenue, north on east side from and including 66th Street, showing the new New York Hospital and Cornell Medical College, the new Medical Center, with the grounds and new laboratory of the
Rockefeller Institute in the right foreground.
Spring 1933.
Keystone-Underwood.

1558291.title: East 66th Street - York Avenue
1558291.folder: East 66th Street - York Avenue, Manhattan, NY

724880f-b.text:
(1)
York Avenue (Avenue A), east side, north from 66th Street. In the right foreground are the grounds of the Rockefeller Institute, which extend up to o7th Street. The block above, where the Williams stone yards used to be around 1890-1900, is a children'a
playground.
On the N.W. corner of 68th Street is the old Central, an apartment house built in 1902. East of it, on 68th Street, are the stables and garage, and then the main plant, of the Central Brewing Company, erected around 1900-02. In this block, prior to about 1895, was Jones Woods Coliseum, known in its last
few years as Empire City Coliseum.
From 69th to 70th Streets may be seen old 1294-1304 Avenue A, tenements built prior to 1910. From 70th to 71st Streets are houses built, in their original form, from about 1890-V5, and
used for some years as cigar factories.
February 13, 1928.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
York Avenue, east side, north from 66th Street, the same view as the preceding. The lamp post in the left foreground, in both pictures, is on the N.W. corner of 66th Street. Rockefeller Institute now has the entire property east of York Avenue up to t8th Street. Notice their fence, with its stone posts. The building to the north is the newest laboratory,
built in 1930.
The New York Hoapital and Cornell Medical College takes up the entire three blocks from 6Bth to 71st Streets, and east to Exterior Street, which is shortly to be rechristened Marie Curie Avenue. The Bio-Chemistry and Pharmacy wing is located on the very N.W. corner of 68th Street where the old Century apartment
house used to stand.
Compare these two views with Wurts Brothers' view of the same
acene early in 1V31.
March 5, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.
PCDTC LEP
